case_name: Sasti alias Satish Chowdhary v. District Magistrate Howrah

facts.text: Writ Petition No. 37 of 1972 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for a writ of habeas corpus.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 37 of 1972.  Under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for a writ in the nature of habeas companypus.

facts.text: Petitioner is Sasti alias Satish Chowdhary detained under section 3 of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: by Sasti alias Satish Chowdhary, who has been ordered by the District Magistrate Howrah to be detained under section 3 of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971  hereinafter referred

facts.text: Detention order passed by District Magistrate Howrah on September 8, 1971 to prevent petitioner from acting prejudicial to maintenance of supplies and services essential to the community.

anchor.surface_text: to as the Act . The order recited that it was made with a view to preventing the petitioner from acting in any manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the companymunity. The order of detention was passed by the District Magistrate on September 8, 1971.

facts.text: Petitioner was found absconding soon after the passing of the detention order.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner, it is stated, was found to be absconding soon after the passing of the order.

facts.text: Petitioner arrested on November 23, 1971 and served with detention order and grounds with vernacular translation on the same day.

anchor.surface_text: He was arrested on November 23, 1971 and was served with the order of detention and the grounds of detention together with vernacular translation thereof on the same day.

facts.text: District Magistrate sent report to State Government on September 8, 1971 about detention order with grounds and particulars.

anchor.surface_text: in the meanwhile on September 8, 1971 the District Magistrate sent report to the State Government about his having made the order of detention along with the grounds of detention and other necessary particulars.

facts.text: State Government approved the detention order on September 10, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: The matter was then companysidered by the State Government. It approved the detention order on September 10, 1971.

facts.text: State Government sent report to Central Government on September 10, 1971 regarding necessity of the order.

anchor.surface_text: The same day the State Government sent report to the Central Government along with necessary particulars regarding the necessity a the order.

facts.text: State Government received petitioner's representation on December 10, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: On December 10, 1971 the State Government received a representation of the petitioner.

facts.text: State Government rejected petitioner's representation on December 21, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: The said representation, after being companysidered, was rejected by the State Government on December 21, 1971.

facts.text: State Government placed petitioner's case before Advisory Board on December 22, 1971 along with representation.

anchor.surface_text: On December 22, 1971 the. State Government placed the case of the petitioner before the Advisory Board. The representation of the petitioner was also sent to the Advisory Board.

facts.text: Advisory Board reported on January 28, 1972 that there was sufficient cause for petitioner's detention after hearing him.

anchor.surface_text: The said Board, after companysidering the material placed before it, including the representation of the petitioner, and after hearing him in person, sent its report to the state on January 28, 1972. Opinion was expressed by the Advisory Board that there was sufficient cause for the petitioners detention.

facts.text: State Government confirmed detention order on February 11, 1972 and communicated to petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: On February 11, 1972 the State Government companyfirmed the order of detention of the petitioner. Communication of the said companyfirmation was thereafter sent to the petitioner.

facts.text: Affidavit filed by Shri Dipak Kumar Rudra, District Magistrate who made the order.

anchor.surface_text: In opposition to the petition Shri Dipak Kumar Rudra, Dist-. rict Magistrate, who made the impugned order, has filed his affidavit.

facts.text: On July 9, 1971 at about 23:30 hours, petitioner and associates Sk. Nazam, Kesta Adhikary, Bablu Das, Kachi Chakravarty and 3/4 others found committing theft of overhead electric wires near Zanana Latrine of Lawrence Co. at Chakkashi by darwans.

anchor.surface_text: On 9.7.71 at about 23.30 hrs. you and your associates Sk. Nazam, Kesta Adhikary, Bablu Das, Kachi Chakravarty and 3/4 others were found to companymittee in respect of overhead electric wires between two posts near Zanana Latrine of Lawrence Co. at Chakkashi by the darwans on duty.

facts.text: Petitioner and Sk. Nazam seen on top of post cutting electric wire, others rolling it; darwans raised alarm and surrounded with local help.

anchor.surface_text: You and your associate Sk. Nazam were seen on the top of the post cutting one end of the electric wire, while your associates were rolling the cut end of the wire from other post. The darwans raised alarm and surrounded you with the help, of local people.

facts.text: Sk. Nazam and others escaped; petitioner and two associates arrested at spot with stolen copper wire.

anchor.surface_text: Your associate Sk. Nazam with other escaped and you and two other of your associates companyld be arrested at the spot with stolen companyper wire.

facts.text: Theft of electric wires created complete dislocation of electric supplies in the area.

anchor.surface_text: This created companyplete dislocation of electric supplies of the area.

facts.text: Court held that the act constituted acting prejudicial to maintenance of supplies and services under section 3(1)(a)(iii) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The above ground of detention, in our opinion, was germane to the object for which a detention order ,can be made under section 3 1  a   iii  of the Act.

facts.text: Mr. Arora argued amicus curiae for petitioner that detention invalid as act is offence under Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Arora has argued the case amicus curiae on behalf of the petitioner, while the State has been reprensented by Mr.Majumdar, Before dealing with the companytention advanced by Mr. Arora, ... It is argued by Mr. Arora that as the act attributed to the- petitioner in the grounds of detention companystituted an offence under the Indian Penal Code,

facts.text: Court rejected the contention that detention cannot be made if act constitutes IPC offence.

anchor.surface_text: This companytention, in our opinion, is devoid of force. It is always open to the detaining authority to pass an order for the detention of a person if the grounds of detention are germane to the object for which a detention order can legally be made.

concepts.interpretation: The detaining authority may, if satisfied with respect to any person that with a view to preventing him from acting in any manner prejudicial to the maintenance of supplies and services essential to the community, it is necessary so to do make an order directing that such person be detained.

anchor.surface_text: Even in cases where a person has been actually prosecuted in a court of law in respect of an incident and has been discharged by the trying magistrate, a valid order of his detention can be passed against him in connection with that very incident.

concepts.interpretation: From the mere fact that a detenu was discharged in a criminal case relating to an incident by a magistrate, it could not be said that the detention order on the basis of that incident was incompetent, nor could it be inferred that it was without basis or mala fide.

issues.text: Whether the petitioner could only be tried in a court of law for the offence under the Indian Penal Code constituted by the act attributed in the grounds of detention, and no order for detention could be made on that score

anchor.surface_text: This created companyplete dislocation of electric supplies of the area. It is argued by Mr. Arora that as the act attributed to the- petitioner in the grounds of detention companystituted an offence under the Indian Penal Code, the petitioner companyld only be tried in a companyrt of law for the offence and numberorder for his detention On that score companyld be made.

issues.text: Whether there is a legal bar to making a detention order if the detaining authority feels there is not sufficient evidence admissible under the Indian Evidence Act for securing a conviction

anchor.surface_text: The detaining authority might well feel that though there was -not sufficient evidence admissible under the Indian Evidenre Act for securing a companyviction, the activities of the person ordered to be detained were of such a nature as to justify the order of detention. There would. be numberlegal bar to the making of detention order in such a case.

issues.text: Whether a valid order of detention can be passed in connection with an incident even if the person has been prosecuted and discharged by the trying magistrate in respect of that incident

anchor.surface_text: Even in cases where a person has been actually prosecuted in a companyrt of law in respect of an incident and has been discharged by the trying magistrate, a valid order of his detention can be passed against him in companynection with that very incident. It was recently observed by this Court in the case of Mohd. Salim Khan v. Shri C. C. Bose Anr.

issues.text: Whether the ground of detention based on theft of electric wires causing complete dislocation of electric supplies is germane to the object of detention under section 3(1)(a)(iii) of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act

anchor.surface_text: The particulars of the incident in the grounds of detention show that the petitioner and his associates companymitted theft in respect of overhead electric wires between two posts near Zanana Latrine of Lawrence Co. at Chakkashi. the above act of the petitioner and his associates created companyplete dislocation of electric supplies of the area. The above ground of detention, in our opinion, was germane to the object for which a detention order ,can be made under section 3 1 a   iii  of the Act.

issues.text: Whether the distinction between law and order and public order or maintenance of supplies and services essential to the community applies to render the detention invalid

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Arora has referred to the case of Pushkar Mukherjee Ors. v. The State of West Bengal 2  wherein this Court dealt with the difference between the companycept of public order and law and order and observed that the said difference was similar to the distinction between public and private crimes in the realm of jurisprudence. It was observed that a line of demarcation must be drawn between serious and aggravated forms of disorder which directly affect the companymunity

arguments.claim: It is always open to the detaining authority to pass an order for the detention of a person if the grounds of detention are germane to the object for which a detention order can legally be made.

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinction is one of degree and extent of reach upon society; acts in different contexts may affect public order or law and order differently; here it affected essential supplies.

arguments.claim: True distinction between law and order and public order is one of degree and extent of the reach of the act upon society; analogy of public vs private crimes not always apt.

anchor.surface_text: Pushkar Mukherjees case 1  was referred to in a later deci- sion of this Court in the case of Arjun Ghosh v. State of West Bengal 2  and it was pointed out that the true distinction between the areas of law and order and public order was one of degree and extent of the reach of the act in question upon society. Acts similar in nature, but companymitted in different companytexts and cir-cumstances might cause different reactions in one case it might affect the problem of the breach of law and order, and in another the breach of public order.

holdings.text: This contention, in our opinion, is devoid of force. It is always open to the detaining authority to pass an order for the detention of a person if the grounds of detention are germane to the object for which a detention order can legally be made.

anchor.surface_text: This contention, in our opinion, is devoid of force. It is always open to the detaining authority to pass an order for the detention of a person if the grounds of detention are germane to the object for which a detention order can legally be made.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects petitioner's claim that IPC offence bars detention; affirms authority to detain if grounds germane to statutory object.

holdings.text: The fact that the particular act of the detenu which provides the reason for the making of the detention order constitutes an offence under the Indian Penal Code would not prevent the detaining authority from passing the order for detention instead of proceeding against him in a court of law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Detention alternative to prosecution even for penal offences if justified by preventive needs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Discharge in criminal case does not preclude preventive detention; cites Mohd. Salim Khan precedent.

holdings.text: It would, however, be imperative that the incident which gives rise to the apprehension in the mind of the detaining authority and induces that authority to pass the order for detention should be relevant and germane to the object for which a detention order can be made under the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Limits detention to germane incidents relevant to statutory purpose.
